document.masterDocTitle: A Rosetta Stone for eastern Pacific Caecidae (Gastropoda: Caenogastropoda)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A Rosetta Stone for eastern Pacific Caecidae (Gastropoda: Caenogastropoda)

Carpenter, 1863: 350

.

subSubSection.paragraph: Original diagnosis. “Shell rather stout, well arcuated, widening towards the aperture, moderately contracted at the summit: ivory white: with about 25 very stout broad prominent not closely approximate rings, with flat summits: apex not very prominent. Length.09 inch; breadth.03 inch. A variety (?) is more slender, and has the ribs less prominent.” Adams (1852: 161) .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution and Habitat. From Cholla Bay, Sonora , Mexico to Salinas, Ecuador including the Galapagos Islands . Intertidal to
100 m .
Abundant subtidally on coarse sand and rubble substrates.

Remarks. The type material of
Caecum firmatum
is comprised of three adults and one subadult ( lectotype MCZ 186578, Figs. 6 F–G). Carpenter (1863) published a review of Adam’s type specimens from Panama , where he considered
C. diminutum
,
C. eburneum
,
C. monstrosum
and
C. pygmaeum
to be conspecific with
C. firmatum
. However, from the citations listed above it would appear Carpenter’s opinion has either been overlooked or ignored for the most part. Yet a comparison of the type specimens via SEM imaging confirms Carpenter’s assessment to be correct for all but one species. As previously stated, ribbed forms of
C. diminutum
( Figs. 6 N–O) may appear similar to
C. firmatum
, but the differences in microsculpture and growth morphology do not support Carpenter’s position.

Caecum firmatum
develops several larger apertural axial ribs that are separated from the rest by a somewhat wider interspace ( Fig. 7I ), but it lacks a true sulcus or varix. The most similar congener is
C. quadratum Carpenter, 1857
, which can be confused when specimens are worn. Both species are quite variable, which has resulted in many synonyms. Axial rib thickness of
C. firmatum
is quite variable. From 1867 to 1869, de Folin described several species:
C. agoniatum
,
C. elegans var. rubella
,
C. impartitum
, and
C. suave
( Figs. 6 P–S), which fall within the species variability of
C. firmatum
.

The holotype of
Caecum pygmaeum
(MCZ 186587, Figs. 6 J–K) may at first appear similar to
C. clathratum Carpenter, 1857
. However,
C. pygmaeum
displays more numerous flattened ribs and lacks the concave interspaces present in
C. clathratum
. The type specimen of
C. pygmaeum
is most likely a heavily eroded
C. firmatum
as synonymized by Carpenter.

There seems to be some confusion regarding the identification of certain caecids found around the Galapagos Islands (
Finet et al . 2016: 28
). To resolve this issue, examinations of the specific lots in question were completed.
Caecum firmatum
is now confirmed to be among those species from the Galapagos Islands as identified by Strong, and recorded by Hertlein & Strong (1955: 136) .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8.
Caecum firmatum
. A . Conceptual reconstruction of growth stages. B . Species distribution map.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Lastly,
Caecum eburneum de Folin, 1886
, is an unrelated species from Australia , which Kisch (1959b) renamed
C. folini
, because de Folin’s name was preoccupied.
